content: @nikomatsakis Is there anything you can think of left to do to close out the 2020 survey? If not, thanks for working with me on this. It was a lot of fun!
I would like to see a doc prepared with a list of things you felt could have been better (poor questions, timing, anything really)
(and the you there is broader than just you: basically a general retro. Asking our translators for their feedback would also be good)

I started a doc for this. Let me know if you don't have permission.
Asking the translators for feedback is a very good idea.
I think asking the translators for feedback is an excellent idea.
We have a doc from last year too ...

Regarding translators: Hey @stream! Please add your thoughts and feedback on the survey into google document. Feel free to create new sections for specific languages if there are things that are specific to your language.

There are also these documents, they might be useful when putting together the 2021 survey.

Tracking for 2021 survey
Notes for 2020 survey

One thing I wish was tracked using the survey is how people feel about dependency bloat and binary sizes. For some of our Rust code we live in "no_std < this space < unbounded resources" . (Zynq-7000 type platforms, with in-memory ram disks for root file system). When stripped release binaries start growing up toward 10MB it's a concern for us. Crates seem to exist either in "no_std" or they are free to grow without bound. I would like to see a question relating to this next year to see if there are more people using Rust in low-resource systems, but not so low as to be no_std.
